Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Physics of the Functional Organization of Chromosomes
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical research at the interface of physics and biology. The goal is to develop statistical physics models of chromosomes in cells that connect their structure to their function. In biology chromosomes are typically described as carriers of genetic information. They are also multi-component and dynamic polymer-like structures made of DNA and proteins that exhibits elements of both regularity and randomness. At the micron scale genes on chromosomes are often localized to particular regions of the cell, within which they undergo diffusive motion. This spatial and temporal organization of chromosomes has been quantitatively characterized using cell biology techniques but the rules that connect these physical properties to their function are largely unknown. The goal of this proposal is to develop coarse grained models based on ideas from statistical physics, which will elucidate the physical mechanisms that link chromosome structure at the micron scale to its function. Two fundamental biological processes will be considered: transcription and DNA recombination. The key question that will be addressed is how these processes are modulated and controlled by the spatial and temporal organization of genomes in cells. One of the key features of the theoretical research supported by this award is a close collaboration with experimental labs that study transcription and recombination quantitatively at the single molecule and single cell level. Theoretical predictions based on specific physical mechanisms of transcription and recombination will be tested in these labs.

This award will support graduate students working at the interface of physics and biology. Physics graduate students engaged in research supported by this award will closely collaborate with biology students in collaborating labs. This mode of graduate training will promote an interdisciplinary research environment that will result in the cross-fertilization of ideas between statistical physics and molecular and cell biology. It will provide physics students with a unique opportunity to learn from students in life-science fields and help train them for research in interdisciplinary teams, which are being deployed with increasing frequency in industry and academia to tackle the outstanding challenges in biology and medicine.


NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Chromosomes are biological structures that perform functions that are essential to life, such as replication of DNA, the repair of damaged DNA, and the synthesis of new proteins. Chromosomes are also large molecular structures consisting of DNA and proteins whose shape and motion within the cell can be described in quantitative details using ideas from physics. The research supported by this award will provide the link between the biological functions of chromosomes and their physical attributes. In particular, it will lead to mathematical descriptions of how the nature of the dynamic and folded state of chromosomes within cells specifies their biological function. A mathematical description will be developed for the search process by which two genes on the same chromosome find each other within the crowded environment of the cell so as to enable the exchange of genetic material that occurs in the process of DNA recombination. Also, there is an abundance of experimental evidence that the folded state of DNA can interfere with the reading of genes in the process of transcription that leads up to protein synthesis, and the proposed research will formulate quantitative models of this unusual structure-function relation. The outcome of these theoretical investigations will be concrete proposals for quantitative experiments on DNA and chromosomes which will be carried out in collaborating biology laboratories that study DNA recombination and transcription. The combined theoretical and experimental approaches will lead to a precise quantitative description of chromosome structure and function.

This award will support graduate students working at the interface of physics and biology. Physics graduate students engaged in theoretical research supported by this award will closely collaborate with biology students. These activities will promote an interdisciplinary research environment that will result in the cross-fertilization of ideas between statistical physics and molecular and cell biology. This environment will also provide the students with a unique opportunity to learn from students in biological fields and help train them for research in interdisciplinary teams which are being deployed with increasing regularity in industry and academia to tackle the outstanding challenges in biology and medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA is the carrier of genetic information and provides the software for the proper functioning of the cell. While this is a useful metaphor what it misses, is that unlike the software that powers our computers whose functioning is unaffected by the physical nature of the medium it is stored in, the physical properties of DNA inside the cell affect how the information it encodes is used by the cell. Understanding the rules that connect the physical properties of the DNA in cells to functions, is the goal of the research we have conducted over the past four years. One way to think about this is that when it comes to DNA its functions are not only encoded in the sequence of its bases but also in its physical properties, and its spatial organization within the cell. While the base-pair code was deciphered more than forty years ago the nature of this “mechanical code” still eludes us.

The DNA that makes up the cell’s genome is many times longer than the cell’s linear dimensions, and therefore needs to be folded up to fit inside. Polymer entropy does part of the job. For example, thermal fluctuations of the E. coli DNA will reduce its linear dimensions from about a millimeter when fully stretched, to roughly five microns. Since the cell is about a micron in length the DNA has to be folded further. This is accomplished by a variety of proteins that bind to DNA and fold it into a composite protein-DNA structure, the chromosome. 

One of the key questions our research has addressed is what is the spatial organization of chromosomes in cells and how it affects the ability of DNA to repair itself after a break has been induced? We have studied a specific DNA-break repair process in yeast cells, which serves as an excellent model system for the process of homologous recombination, which is common to all living cells. Homologous recombination is a mechanism by which a cell can fix a break in its DNA whereby the cell uses as a template for repair an equivalent DNA sequence to the one that was damaged.  For this process to commence the break and the homologous (template) sequence have to come in close spatial proximity. How these two sequences find each other in the large and crowded volume of the nucleus, is a specific question we have addressed.

We have developed a mathematical model that describes the folded state of chromosomes in yeast and then we tested this model against experiments. Furthermore, we have discovered that cells manipulate the folded state of chromosomes by creating Velcro-like links between distant regions along the chromosome so as to bring the homologous sequences in close proximity. Using ideas from polymer physics we were able to put forward a mathematical model that described the likelihood that a particular sequence is used for DNA break repair, depending on where it is physically located on the chromosome. We then carried out experiments on yeast cells to test the predictions of our theory and found good agreement between the two. We are now in a position to predict the likelihood of repair of a DNA break by homologous recombination by knowing the where on the genome is the homologous sequence located.  

Another key function of DNA is to provide the cell with information about which proteins should be produced and when. The first step in the protein-making process is transcription, whereby the gene on the DNA is read by a machine, the RNA polymerase. The polymerase produces a molecule, messenger RNA, that is a carbon copy of the gene and serves as the template for the protein-making machine, the ribosome. Whether or not a particular gene will be read is determined by the control regions of DNA which serve as ON and OFF switches. These switches are flipped by the action of proteins, transcription factors, that bind to DNA. How this is all orchestrated in cells, namely how the dynamics of transcription factor binding to DNA leads to some genes being ON and others OFF is still poorly understood.

We have contributed to the deciphering of this puzzle (the “regulatory code”) by developing mathematical models that connect measurements of the dynamics of messenger RNA production to the dynamics of protein-DNA binding. We have shown how different patterns of biding and unbinding lead to specific experimental signatures in the times between successive RNA production events. This will allow biologists who do measurements on RNA production in live cells to interpret their results in the context of simple mechanistic models of transcription.

Overall these and other efforts supported by this grant are helping turn cell biology into a quantitative science. The hope is that one day this might lead to the transformation of medicine into an engineering discipline.
